channel.title: W3 Markup Validation
channel.description:
Well here is my link to my validation page with errors on:
http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.off2.com&charset=%28detect+automatically%29&doctype=Inline&group=0&verbose=1
Basically, I dont know how to correct any of these... Can anyone shed some light?
Thanks[br][size=1]Posted on: September 27, 2007, 02:50:53 AM[/size][hr]Ok sorted it... Just had to end the meta tags with /> and remove the width and height attributes from an image.
[img]http://www.w3.org/Icons/valid-xhtml10[/img] :D

item.title: W3 Markup Validation
item.dc:creator: @TestDummy TestDummy
item.description:
@TestDummy wrote:

What he means is that the “Strict” document type definition is better than the “Transitional”.
Transitional allows old, depreciated elements, whereas Strict forbids them.

Basically, Strict forces you do to things without the older elements.

# XHTML 1.0 Strict is the same as HTML 4.01 Strict, but follows XML syntax rules. # XHTML 1.0 Transitional is the same as HTML 4.01 Transitional, but follows XML syntax rules. It supports everything found in XHTML 1.0 Strict, but also permits the use of a number of elements and attributes that are judged presentational, in order to ease the transition from HTML 3.2 and earlier. These include , , , and .

Read full topic

item.title: W3 Markup Validation
item.dc:creator: @Kimber Kimber
item.description:
@Kimber wrote:

and strict DTD > transitional DTD

I dont know about this/what it means, care to enlighten me?

item.title: W3 Markup Validation
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Kimber, post:1, topic:146756”]Well here is my link to my validation page with errors on:

http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.off2.com&charset=(detect+automatically)&doctype=Inline&group=0&verbose=1

Basically, I dont know how to correct any of these… Can anyone shed some light?

Thanks[br][size=1]Posted on: September 27, 2007, 02:50:53 AM[/size][hr]Ok sorted it… Just had to end the meta tags with /> and remove the width and height attributes from an image.

:D[/quote]
i say: don’t use XHTML at all, HTML is just as clean, opera, firefox and IE have all pushed towards development of HTML 5, and xhtml usually gets parsed the wrong way.
my 2 cents

edit: and strict DTD > transitional DTD

Read full topic
